node.text: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, c. 1960. Photo c/o Black LGBT Archivists Society of Philadelphia. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #Night
San Francisco, c. 1979. Photographer unknown. #HavePrideInHistory #Night

“I’ll tell you what freedom is to me: No Fear!
.
“I mean, really, no fear. If I could have that . . . half of my life. No fear. Lots of children have no fear. That’s the closest way. . .that’s the only way I can describe it, but that’s not all of it, but it is something to really, really feel . . .
.
Like a new way of seeing. Like a new way of seeing.” – Nina Simone (Feb. 21, 1933 – Apr. 21, 2003), 1968. Footage from “Nina Simone: An Historical Perspective,” a Peter Rodis production, 1970. #HavePrideInHistory #NinaSimone

“When have any of us ever done enough?” - Barbara Jordan, 1977
.
Picture: Barbara Jordan (Feb. 21, 1936 – Jan. 17, 1996), c. 1990.
.
Barbara Jordan, who was born eighty-four years ago today, was a lawyer, educator, politician, and civil rights leader. A Democrat, she was the first Black person elected to the Texas Senate after Reconstruction, the first (and only) Black woman to serve as governor of Texas (she served as acting governor for one day), the first Southern Black woman elected to the U.S. House of Representatives, and the first Black woman to deliver a keynote address at a Democratic National Convention. Diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1973, Jordan also made accessibility a component of her activism, and her visibility as a powerful woman who used a wheelchair drew attention to the ongoing struggle for disability justice.
.
Barbara Jordan died of complications from pneumonia on January 17, 1996; she was fifty-nine.
.
Throughout her life, Jordan guarded her privacy with great care; among friends, family, and colleagues, however, it was no secret that she was a lesbian. In the late 1960s, Jordan met Nancy Earl, an educational psychologist, and the two entered a devoted partnership that lasted until Jordan’s death.
.
In life, neither Jordan nor Earl acknowledged the nature of their relationship in a public setting beyond those they trusted. Upon Jordan's death, however, her obituary listed Nancy, her "longtime companion," among her survivors. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #BarbaraJordan

“Once we had a country and we thought it fair,

Look in the atlas and you'll find it there:

We cannot go there now, my dear, we cannot go there now.” – Wystan Hugh Auden, “Refugee Blues”
.
Picture: Christopher Isherwood & W.H. Auden (Feb. 21, 1907 – Sept. 29, 1973), 1938, c/o @nationalportraitgallery.
.
W.H. Auden, who was born 113 years ago today, was a prolific English poet, playwright, essayist, and critic, best-known for his hundreds of published poems, ranging in style from strict traditionalism to obscure modernism, and in content from love (“Funeral Blues”) to sociopolitics (“September 1, 1939”) to psychology (“The Age of Anxiety”) to religion (“For the Time Being”).
.
Auden’s lifelong friendship, and intermittent sexual relationship, with Christopher Isherwood pushed both men in their creative and professional pursuits. In 1939, the pair left Britain for the United States (a move widely seen as a betrayal), and Auden’s reputation suffered.
.
Living in New York, Auden met the poet Chester Kallman, and the men entered a relationship which Auden referred to as a marriage. (In strictly legal terms, Auden was, in fact, married to Erika Mann, the openly lesbian daughter of Thomas Mann.) Kallman, who eschewed monogamy, ended the relationship, though the men lived together as companions until Auden’s death.
.
Auden later summarized his emotional life in a couplet: “If equal affection cannot be / Let the more loving one be me.”
.
W.H. Auden died of a heart attack on September 29, 1973; he was 66.
.
The 1994 film “Four Weddings and a Funeral” brought renewed attention to Auden’s work when, during the funeral scene, Matthew, a gay man played by John Hannah, eulogized his lover by reading Auden's “Funeral Blues”:
.
“He was my North, my South, my East and West,

My working week and my Sunday rest,

My noon, my midnight, my talk, my song;

I thought that love would last forever: I was wrong.” #HavePrideInHistory #WHAuden

“MAKE THAT MOVE – FIGHT RACISM – DARE TO STRUGGLE – DARE TO WIN – DYKES AGAINST RACISM EVERYWHERE,” Dykes Against Racism Everywhere (DARE) pinback, New York City, c. 1982. From the collection of @lgbt_history.
.
In early February 1980, after attending a “Death to the Klan” rally in Greensboro, North Carolina, several lesbian activists from New York City decided to organize a new coalition, Dykes Against Racism Everywhere (DARE). Throughout the early 1980s, DARE sounded a radical alarm on vital issues that, left unaddressed by dominant cultures within and beyond the gay community, have continued to disproportionately impact queer people of color for decades.
.
Identifying the clear connections between politicians’ calls to “clamp down on crime,” a huge increase in prison construction, and the all-out war being waged on low-income communities by police across the country, DARE urged the queer community to focus on the booming prison industrial complex.
.
As the cost of living skyrocketed in Greenwich Village, DARE members wrote that “gentrification could destroy our community as we know it,” making life particularly difficult for transgender people and those of color.
.
And, in perhaps its most controversial fight, DARE criticized the organizers of New York City’s 1982 Pride events for “inviting a cop—who happens to be gay—to speak at the rally.” Lambasting the desperate attempt to prove that “respectable” queer people are everywhere, DARE wrote that “we still need to be clear on who our allies really are. . . . In our opinion, the police are not now, nor will they ever be, our allies.”
.
As with much of the radical prescience throughout queer history, the voices of the most marginalized were all-but ignored in the early 1980s.
.
We cannot win unless we fight. Dare to struggle. Dare to win. #Night

“You know, there is always the storm that strike you when at least less expected [sic].” – Gaétan Dugas, 1982
.
Gaétan Dugas, who was born 67 years ago today, was a French-Canadian airline steward who, after being one of the first people in North America diagnosed with Kaposi’s sarcoma (then-known as “gay cancer”), died of AIDS-related illness in March 1984. Dugas—whose name is linked to the shamefully inaccurate ”Patient Zero” figure from “And The Band Played On” by Randy Shilts—was, in fact, a fairly typical gay man who, like too many others, fell victim to ignorance, neglect, and hate.
.
In a 1982 study analyzing the sexual histories of men with AIDS in Southern California, researchers benefitted from one man having kept particularly detailed records of past sexual encounters. Because that patient was from outside California, doctors referred to him as “Patient O” (as in, Patient Outside California); later, staff at the Centers for Disease Control interpreted the nickname as “Patient 0” (zero).
.
In the mid-‘80s, as gay journalist Randy Shilts researched the early history of HIV/AIDS, he stumbled upon the “Patient Zero” nickname—which he later called “catchy”—and created a tale of a seemingly psychotic killer, “jet-setting between coasts, spreading the AIDS virus.” After the 1987 release of Shilts’ “And The Band Played On,” Gaétan Dugas was dubbed “The Man Who Gave Us AIDS.”
.
In 2014, Richard McKay published a groundbreaking article (later a book) detailing the facts of Dugas’ life and the ways in which Shilts exploited his story. In an October 2016 article in “Nature,” new information regarding the origins and trajectory of the HIV-virus helped show conclusively that Dugas played no special role in the spread of the virus. “The new analysis shows that Mr. Dugas’s blood, sampled in 1983, contained a viral strain already infecting men in New York City before he began visiting gay bars [t]here in 1974.”
.
Gaétan Dugas died on March 30, 1984, shortly after his 31st birthday. A panel on the AIDS Memorial Quilt, one of many dedicated to Gaétan, reads simply: “Tell my story, clear my name, why do they need someone to blame?” #GaetanDugas

“If you want Gay Power, then you’re going to have to fight for it. And you’re going to have fight until you win.” – Sylvia Rivera
.
Picture: “AND GOD CREATED HE AND SHE BUT HE ALSO CREATED ME!” Sylvia Rivera (right), Christopher Street Liberation Day, June 26, 1983. Photo by Steve Zabel, c/o @lgbtcenternyc.
.
Sylvia Rivera, who died 18 years ago today, was a parent of the queer liberation movement, having helped found the Gay Liberation Front and the Gay Activists Alliance, and co-founding (with Marsha P. Johnson) the Street Transvestite Action Revolutionaries, a group dedicated to serving homeless drag queens, trans women, and sex workers.
.
From the beginning, Rivera fought the mainstream gay movement’s exclusion of trans and gender non-specific people from social and legal victories.
.
In 1973, for example, after Sylvia fought for years for a New York City anti-discrimination ordinance, mainstream leaders struck, at the last minute, portions of the bill covering the trans community. (The bill still didn’t pass.) During that summer’s Gay Pride, Sylvia demanded an opportunity to address the rally in Washington Square Park, berating the crowd for ignoring the most marginalized members of the community in favor of empty promises of “gay rights.”
.
After the hostility of 1973, Sylvia disappeared from the scene for a few years, returning to Pride in 1977 with a reminder that she’d carry for years: “AND GOD CREATED HE AND SHE BUT HE ALSO CREATED ME!”
.
Sylvia didn’t fully return to the movement she’d help create until the mid-1990s, though a marriage-focused gay community still failed to give her the respect she deserved. Near life near the end of her life, Rivera took particular exception with the Human Rights Campaign, a lobbying organization that, for many years, consciously and conspicuously excluded the trans community from most legislative efforts. In 2001, Rivera said that "one of our main goals now is to destroy the Human Rights Campaign, because I'm tired of sitting on the back of the bumper."
.
Sylvia Rivera died of complications from liver cancer on Feb. 19, 2002; she was 50. #HavePrideInHistory #SaintSylvia

Note: This post is graphic (violence).
.
“I share with many Americans a sense of grief and outrage at the tragic and violent death of Billy Jack Gaither. . . .This heinous and cowardly crime touches the conscience of our country, just as the terrible murders of James Byrd and Matthew Shepard did last year.” – Bill Clinton, March 5, 1999.
.
Picture: Billy Jack Gaither (Jan. 21, 1960 – Feb. 19, 1999), c. 1990.
.
On February 19, 1999, twenty-one years ago today, thirty-nine year old Billy Jack Gaither was beaten to death with an ax handle and his body burned on a pile of old tires in his hometown of Sylacauga, Alabama. His killers, Steven Mullins and Charles Butler, claimed they acted in response to Gaither making sexual advances; both were sentenced to life without parole.
.
Until his death, @nytimes reported, Gaither “lived with his disabled parents, tending to their needs, cooking dinner and cleaning up, singing in the choir of his church. His parents swear they had no idea he was gay.”
.
But, the Times continued, “the small group of gay residents in this central Alabama city of 13,000 knew [Gaither] as one of their own. . . . A friend said Mr. Gaither had never wanted to hurt his deeply religious, Baptist parents by revealing the nature of his sexuality. Now his parents and the rest of Sylacauga have found out in the worst possible way.”
.
Gaither’s parents, “who knew him as the kindest of their four boys,” had to struggle not only with the weight of their son’s murder but also with the implications of being part of a culture that kept Billy’s closet door so tightly shut.
.
“Whatever he did,” his mother said, “he never brought it home.” She added, “And whether he was or not, it don’t make me love him any less. He was my young’un.” Whether “he was gay or not,” Gaither’s father said, “that still didn’t give them no right to kill him.”
.
Billy Jack Gaither would have turned 60 last month.
.
In March 2019, just weeks after the twentieth anniversary of Gaither’s murder, Steven Mullins was stabbed to death by another inmate at the St. Clair Correctional Facility; Mullins was 45. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #BillyJackGaither

“Straight guys are jerks. Gay guys are jerks. Straight women are jerks. That leaves lesbians. And they’re up in their ivory tower somewhere laughing their heads off at the rest of us.” – Nick (Steve Buscemi), “Parting Glances” (1986)
.
Picture: Steve Buscemi, “Parting Glances,” written and directed by Bill Sherwood, 1986.
.
On February 19, 1986, thirty-four years ago today, “Parting Glances,” writer-director Bill Sherwood’s only feature film, opened at New York City’s Embassy 72nd Street theater. The low-budget, “very independent” film—which introduced the world to Steve Buscemi—was a revelation in its depiction of queer life in the age of AIDS.
.
“The qualities one likes best about [] ‘Parting Glances,’” @latimes said, “are its immaculate, flashing wit, its easy grace and the nimble but compassionate way it deals with a potentially explosive subject—in this case, a 24-hour crisis in the lives of three young gay Manhattanites, one of whom [Steve Buscemi’s Nick] is dying of AIDS.“
.
Nick, @nytimes explained, “is the most unsentimental and original figure. . . . Playing a rock singer dying of AIDS, Mr. Buscemi has a powerfully anarchic presence . . . and he makes a memorable impression. It is to both his and the film’s credit that the anguish of AIDS is presented as part of a larger social fabric, understood in context, and never in a maudlin light.”
.
The film also was groundbreaking in its presentation of the relationship between Robert (John Bolger) and Michael (Richard Ganoung), who are nonchalantly physically affectionate and sexual with one another in ways that had rarely been seen in American cinema.
.
“Parting Glances” is one of the few movies of the era that has withstood the test of time, offering a uniquely queer perspective into the idiosyncrasies of New York City’s gay community just as the reality of an epidemic took hold.
.
Bill Sherwood, who never made another film, died of AIDS-related complications in February 1990; he was thirty-seven. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #PartingGlances

“I’d like to express myself. Anyway I can, for as long as I’m capable. I’d like to try everything at least once.” - Jackie Curtis, 1970
.
Picture: Jackie Curtis (Feb. 19, 1947 – May 15, 1985), c. 1970s. Photo © Leee Black Childers.
.
Jackie Curtis, who was born 73 years ago today, was an actress, playwright, singer, and Warhol superstar, best known for her roles in the Andy Warhol/Paul Morrissey films “Flesh” (1968) and “Women in Revolt” (1971).
.
Curtis was raised by her maternal grandmother, Ann Uglialoro, a.k.a. Slugger Ann; the family ran a popular bar, Slugger Ann’s, in the East Village from the 1950s until 1980.
.
In the mid-‘60s, Curtis made her stage debut in Tom Eyen’s “Miss Neferititi,” and she soon began writing her own plays, most of which revolved around and/or featured queer—and specifically trans—artists. Candy Darling, Holly Woodlawn, and Curtis appeared with the likes of Harvey Fierstein (@theharveyfierstein), Jayne County, Penny Arcade, and Robert DeNiro in plays like “Glamour, Glory and Gold,” “Amerika Cleopatra,” “Femme Fatale,” and “Heaven Grand in Amber Orbit.”
.
In the late 1960s, Curtis met Andy Warhol, who later called her “a pioneer without a frontier.” Curtis and Candy Darling appeared in Warhol’s “Flesh” (1968) and, with the addition of Holly Woodlawn, in “Women in Revolt” (1971). In 1972, Curtis was among the icons fictionalized in Lou Reed’s “Walk on the Wild Side,” with Reed referencing her drug addictions and obsession with James Dean. In 1974, Curtis and Woodlawn appeared in the highly acclaimed “Cabaret in the Sky” at the New York Cultural Center.
.
Curtis left an indelible mark on fashion with her trailblazing style that came to be associated with glam rock; she would, for example, often be seen in lipstick, glitter, heels, and ripped dresses and stockings, a combination of “trash” and “glamour” that’s still seen today. Members of The New York Dolls, the seminal rock-punk-glam band, included Curtis among their fashion inspirations.
.
Jackie Curtis died of a heroin overdose on May 15, 1985; she was 38. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #JackieCurtis
“‘I AM DELIBERATE AND AFRAID OF NOTHING’ – AUDRE LORDE” pinback, c. 2000s. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #Night

“We are citizens of the most powerful country on earth—we are also citizens of a country that stands upon the wrong side of every liberation struggle on earth. Feel what that means. It is a reality that haunts each of our lives and that can help inform our dreams. It’s not about altruism, it’s about self-preservation. Survival.” - Audre Lorde, 1989
.
Picture: Audre Lorde (Feb. 18, 1934 – Nov. 17, 1992), c. 1980s. Photo © Dagmar Shultz.
.
Audre Lorde, who was born eighty-six years ago today, was a self-described Black lesbian mother warrior poet, best known as a visionary in Black feminist thought and for her analyses of the intersectional nature of all oppression.
.
“Throughout all of Audre Lorde’s writing, both nonfiction and fiction, a single theme surfaces repeatedly,” Allison Kimmich wrote. “The Black lesbian feminist poet activist reminds her readers that they ignore differences among people at their peril… Instead, Lorde suggests, differences in race or class must serve as a ‘reason for celebration and growth.’”
.
Beyond this, any attempt to provide a brief overview of Lorde’s prolific and profound body of work feels disingenuous. Instead, we urge everyone to read and grapple with “Sister Outsider,” “Zami,” “I Am Your Sister,” “Cables to Rage,” or whatever you can find.
.
“Did you ever read my words,” Lorde asked, “or did you merely finger through them for quotations which you thought might valuably support an already conceived idea concerning some old and distorted connection between us?”
.
Audre Lorde died of liver cancer on November 17, 1992; she was fifty-eight. Before her death, she took an additional name, Gamba Adisa, which means "Warrior: She Who Makes Her Meaning Known." #HavePrideInHistory #AudreLorde #GambaAdisa #Black #Lesbian #Mother #Warrior #Poet

“WE’RE HERE, WE’RE QUEER, WE HATE THE FUCKING PRESIDENT!” ACT UP/NY (@actupny) members, including legendary poet & artist Assotto Saint (center, with coffin), protest outside a fundraiser by then-president George H. W. Bush, New York City, July 1990. Photo/copyright by the incredible @dona_ann_mcadams. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #PresidentsDay

“I want a dyke for president. I want a person
with aids for president and I want a fag for
vice president and I want someone with no
health insurance and I want someone who grew
up in a place where the earth is so saturated
with toxic waste that they didn’t have a
choice about getting leukemia. I want a
president that had an abortion at sixteen and
I want a candidate who isn’t the lesser of two
evils and I want a president who lost their
last lover to aids, who still sees that in
their eyes every time they lay down to rest,
who held their lover in their arms and knew
they were dying. I want a president with no
air conditioning, a president who has stood on
line at the clinic, at the dmv, at the welfare
office and has been unemployed and layed off and
sexually harrassed and gaybashed and deported.
I want someone who has spent the night in the
tombs and had a cross burned on their lawn and
survived rape. I want someone who has been in
love and been hurt, who respects sex, who has
made mistakes and learned from them. I want a
Black woman for president. I want someone with
bad teeth [and an attitude], someone who has
eaten [that nasty] hospital food, someone who
crossdresses and has done drugs and been in
therapy. I want someone who has committed
civil disobedience. And I want to know why this
isn’t possible. I want to know why we started
learning somewhere down the line that a president
is always a clown: always a john and never
a hooker. Always a boss and never a worker,
always a liar, always a thief and never caught.” - Zoe Leonard, “I want a president,” 1992. #HavePrideInHistory #BeAngry #StayAngry #Night

“You have no idea who’s watching you. You have no idea who you will impress and inform and change and enhearten and empower. You have no idea who will take just something you said from your heart . . . or the way you walk or the way you dress. There’s some 14-year-old who says, ‘I like that.’ You have no idea who you will inform because all of us are caged birds, have been and will be again. Caged by somebody else’s ignorance. Caged because of someone else’s small-mindedness. Caged because of someone else’s fear, hate and sometimes, caged by our own lack of courage. . . . When we have enough courage to come out—I don’t mean just out of the closet, I mean out of your spirit—when you have enough courage to stand and say, ‘I came here to say,’ it’s amazing. You have no idea who you will inform.” – Maya Angelou
.
Picture: James Baldwin and Maya Angelou, Beverly Hills, California, c. 1960s. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #Sunday

Kenny Chanel and Bobby Revlon, House of Milan Ball, Lesbian & Gay Community Services Center (now The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, @lgbtcenternyc), New York City, 1990. Photo/copyright by Chantal Regnault (@chantalregnaultphoto). #HavePrideInHistory #SaturdayNight
"THE MORE I KNOW MEN, THE MORE I LOVE MY DOG," Marsha P. Johnson and friend, New York City, c. 1985. Photo by Randy Wicker. #HavePrideInHistory #PayItNoMind #ValentinesDay #Mood
"LOVE," c. 1940s. Photo from Trent Kelley's "Hidden in the Open: A Photographic Essay of Afro-American Male Couples." #HavePrideInHistory #Night
“BLACK BY BIRTH, GAY BY GOD, PROUD BY CHOICE," Million Man March, Washington, D.C., October 16, 1995. Photo by @elvertxbarnes. #HavePrideInHistory #BlackLivesMatter #BHM
"HELP THE POLICE — BEAT YOURSELF UP,” ACT UP/San Francisco pinback, 1989. #HavePrideInHistory #Night

“POLICE LAWLESSNESS MUST BE STOPPED” – “PEACE IN SILVERLAKE” – “STOP ILLEGAL SEARCH AND SEIZURE” – “BLUE FASCISM MUST GO,” The Black Cat, Los Angeles, Feb. 11, 1967. Photo c/o @onearchives.
.
Just as the clock struck midnight on January 1, 1967, and patrons of Silver Lake’s Black Cat bar celebrated the beginning of a new year, undercover officers unleashed one of the most violent attacks on a queer establishment on record.
.
“Perhaps it was the reeking mass brutality of this raid that did it,” Jim Kepner wrote at the time. “Or it may have been the slow, cumulative effect of years of hard work by small, struggling organizations telling homophiles that they could fight back.” Whatever it was, “that night, something changed.”
.
After the raid, a group of activists—known as Personal Rights in Defense and Education (PRIDE)—“planned and organized a double-pronged strategy of resistance – in the street and in the courtroom.”
.
For the first time, many of those arrested argued their treatment was wrong, “not on the basis of entrapment, but on the legal theory that they had equal rights…That was a tremendous mind-set change.”
.
At the same time, PRIDE (probably, as Lillian Faderman noted, “the first application of the word to gay politics”) worked with the Right of Assembly and Movement Committee (ramcom)—formed to protest increased police brutality against anti-war and civil rights activists—to plan a demonstration. In a first for Los Angeles, “gays and straights joined forces to fight against the police violence that affected so many communities.”
.
On February 11, 1967, fifty-three years ago today, about 500 protesters gathered at the Black Cat for perhaps the largest queer demonstration to date in the U.S.
.
According to the Free Press, L.A.’s “homosexual community—long reluctant to come out in the open—now appears ready to launch an entirely new kind of civil rights drive. A drive demanding equal treatment for sexual minorities.”
.
PRIDE soon launched its own newsletter, eventually calling it The Los Angeles Advocate. Despite changes of ownership, politics, and style, that publication—now known as @theadvocatemag—still exists. #HavePrideInHistory
“I DESERVE LOVE • TO BE TRUSTED • SEXUAL PLEASURE • FRIENDSHIP • HAPPINESS • FREEDOM • RESPECT” pinback, c. 1980s. from collection of @lgbt_history. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #Night

“GOD LOVES FAGS,” March on Washington for Lesbian, Gay and Bi Equal Rights and Liberation, Washington, DC, April 25, 1993. Photo/copyright by @lynnharrisb, c/o @onearchives. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory #Sunday

“WE’RE PROUD OF OUR GAY CHILDREN,” National March on Washington for Lesbian & Gay Rights, Washington, D.C., October 14, 1979. Photo by Harry Eberlin, c/o @waygayphilly, John Wilcox Archives. #lgbthistory #HavePrideInHistory
